learning_target: Students develop a model of a chemical reaction that explains new substances are formed by the regrouping of atoms and that mass is conserved.

criteria.title: Develop a model that explains atoms regroup and are conserved in chemical reactions

levels.name: Proficient
levels.description: Model shows the correct reactant (water) and product molecules (oxygen and hydrogen gas) and demonstrates that all atoms are conserved before and after the reaction.

levels.name: Developing
levels.description: Model shows either the correct reactant and product molecules or that atoms are conserved, but not both.

levels.name: Beginning
levels.description: Model does not show correct reactants/products or atom conservation.

examples.proficient: My model shows water (H2O) splitting into hydrogen gas and oxygen gas. The same number of each type of atom appears before and after the reaction.
examples.developing: Water turns into hydrogen and oxygen, but I didn’t label the number of atoms.
examples.beginning: Water molecules change into something else and some atoms disappear.

criteria.title: State how a model shows atoms rearrange in a chemical reaction to produce new substances

levels.name: Proficient
levels.description: Explains that new substances (hydrogen and oxygen gas) are made from atoms of the reactant (water) and that the atoms break apart and rearrange to form new molecules.

levels.name: Beginning
levels.description: Does not indicate that new substances come from rearrangement of atoms from the reactants.

examples.proficient: The atoms in water molecules rearrange to form new substances—hydrogen gas and oxygen gas.
examples.beginning: Water turns into gases but I’m not sure how the atoms change.

criteria.title: State how a model shows mass is conserved in a chemical reaction

levels.name: Proficient
levels.description: States mass is conserved and provides evidence that both sides of the reaction have the same number of each type of atom.

levels.name: Developing
levels.description: States atoms are conserved but does not specify all atom types or amounts.

levels.name: Beginning
levels.description: Does not state that mass or atoms are conserved.

examples.proficient: The model shows the same number of oxygen and hydrogen atoms before and after the reaction, so mass is conserved.
examples.developing: Mass stays the same, but I didn’t count the atoms.
examples.beginning: Some atoms go away so the mass changes.
